children.subject: Hi Michael, I'm a member of The House Fund Team. The instructor is asking that students sign up for the course right after filling out the application.
For the Build a Startup in AI, can we submit our application before signing up for the course? I don't want to drop a course so I can add the class and end up getting rejected :/.

history.content:
Hi EECS 101 community, I want to share two new Berkeley Engineering courses next spring (Spring 2021) that students can get involved with. They are both project courses in partnership with industry (you can think about them as a semester-long hackathon), which is quite exciting.

Sp 21 Project Course: Building with Blockchain for Web 3.0

There is a new technical project course next semester, centered around building prototypes for Web 3.0. If you don’t know already, Web 3.0 is a movement that is rebuilding the internet to make it more decentralized and embraces security, privacy, and openness! 


This course partners with three leading blockchain protocols to support students: Polkadot (created by the co-inventor of Ethereum, Gavin Wood), Tezos, and Algorand (led by Dr. Silvio Micali, a Turing award winner with his PhD from UC Berkeley). 


Over the semester, you’ll work in teams, choose one of the three technology providers, build a working prototype, and present on our course demo day, all while receiving continuous developer support from technical experts, guest lecturers, our protocol partners and more! You will also build a foundation in entrepreneurship, design thinking, and business fundamentals through the innovation engineering method.


This course is 3-units and also counts towards the certificate in Entrepreneurship and Technology. Here’s the course homepage with more details and the official listing (undergrad) and (grad). This course is organized by the SCET (Sutardja Center for Entrepreneurship & Technology), Berkeley Blockchain Xcelerator, and Blockchain at Berkeley.  

Sp 21 Project Course: Build a Startup in AI

The House Fund is running a 3-unit class in spring semester called “Build a Startup: Real Applications of Artificial Intelligence” and it is going to be awesome.

If you want to actually build a startup and you’re reasonably technical, this class is for you. The class will break you into teams, give you AI/ML startup ideas (or let you choose your own), and walk you through topics + exercises each week so that you end up with a working prototype, a startup pitch, and tons of contacts (AI tech experts, VCs, Execs, etc). Plus it’s a great way to get connected to The House Fund.

Here’s the application link and the class listing.
history.subject: Spring 21 New Technical Project Courses
